PROFESSOR: So we
study group theory not to admire group
theory but to use it to make sense of spectra.

And usually, when
it's taught, it's taught as a separate
and beautiful object.

And the goal of trying to use
it to ask the kinds of questions

that we would want answers
to is practicing spectroscopy is usually hidden. And so, what do we want to ask?

We would like to know, from
how a spectrum appears, what it tells us qualitatively
about the molecule.

And as much as
possible, I'm going to be trying to address that.

And one of the most
important techniques is creating a reducible
representation

using cartoon-like
ideas and reducing it

so that we can
figure out what are the vibrations of the molecule. And then we find out what
are their symmetries.

And then we find out what
will their spectra look like, because a given
vibrational symmetry

implies a certain rotational
structure in the spectrum.

And there are beautiful
examples in the literature

of the use of this
kind of logic to decide on the shape of a molecule.

And we will soon be starting
talking in a case study

way of electronic spectra. And one of the most
beautiful things

that happened about 60
years ago was the proof

that acetylene undergoes
a qualitative change in geometric structure upon
excitation from the ground

state to the electronically
excited state, and that this could be proven
by the selective use of group

theory. A similar thing happens
with formaldehyde, although the change in
structure is not so dramatic,

and it's more subtle. And that is, formaldehyde in the
ground state is playing around. In the excited state, it's bent.

But the barrier to
planarity is very low. And so, one uses group theory
to look at the spectrum,

and you see two
different answers, depending on whether
you're looking at low vibrational levels
or higher vibrational.

So I hope that I will be
able to give enough tools so

that you can see how we get
the qualitative information quickly.
